channel.title: Up First
channel.description: NPR's Up First is the news you need to start your day. The biggest stories and ideas — from politics to pop culture — in 10 minutes. Hosted by Rachel Martin, David Greene and Steve Inskeep, with reporting and analysis from NPR News. Available weekdays by 6 a.m. ET. Subscribe and listen, then support your local NPR station at donate.npr.org.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015-2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only
channel.itunes:summary: NPR's Up First is the news you need to start your day. The biggest stories and ideas — from politics to pop culture — in 10 minutes. Hosted by Rachel Martin, David Greene and Steve Inskeep, with reporting and analysis from NPR News. Available weekdays by 6 a.m. ET. Subscribe and listen, then support your local NPR station at donate.npr.org.
channel.itunes:author: NPR

item.title: Tuesday, February 5th, 2019
item.description: The White House says the president will deliver a unifying message in his State of the Union. Calls mount for Virginia Governor Ralph Northam to resign. And Russia reacts to the U.S. withdrawal from the INF Treaty.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: Tuesday, February 5th, 2019
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: The White House says the president will deliver a unifying message in his State of the Union. Calls mount for Virginia Governor Ralph Northam to resign. And Russia reacts to the U.S. withdrawal from the INF Treaty.
item.content:encoded: The White House says the president will deliver a unifying message in his State of the Union. Calls mount for Virginia Governor Ralph Northam to resign. And Russia reacts to the U.S. withdrawal from the INF Treaty.

item.title: Monday, February 4th, 2019
item.description: Virginia's governor is under fire for a racist photo. Jury deliberations get underway for drug kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman. And Pope Francis is on a historic trip to the Arabian Peninsula.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: Monday, February 4th, 2019
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: Virginia's governor is under fire for a racist photo. Jury deliberations get underway for drug kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman. And Pope Francis is on a historic trip to the Arabian Peninsula.
item.content:encoded: Virginia's governor is under fire for a racist photo. Jury deliberations get underway for drug kingpin Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman. And Pope Francis is on a historic trip to the Arabian Peninsula.

item.title: Friday, February 1st, 2019
item.description: The Senate voted to rebuke President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from Syria and Afghanistan. New disclosures in a lawsuit against Purdue Pharma allege that the company's owners pushed to sell higher doses of the highly addictive drug OxyContin. And a new experiment in the U.S. is aimed at creating gene-edited human embryos.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: Friday, February 1st, 2019
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: The Senate voted to rebuke President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from Syria and Afghanistan. New disclosures in a lawsuit against Purdue Pharma allege that the company's owners pushed to sell higher doses of the highly addictive drug OxyContin. And a new experiment in the U.S. is aimed at creating gene-edited human embryos.
item.content:encoded: The Senate voted to rebuke President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from Syria and Afghanistan. New disclosures in a lawsuit against Purdue Pharma allege that the company's owners pushed to sell higher doses of the highly addictive drug OxyContin. And a new experiment in the U.S. is aimed at creating gene-edited human embryos.

item.title: Thursday, January 31st, 2019
item.description: The polar vortex is paralyzing the Midwest. At least eight people have died in the extreme cold. Facebook and Google are in hot water for paying users to download apps that monitor their phone usage. And the U.S. and China enter their final day in high-stakes trade talks.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only
item.itunes:title: Thursday, January 31st, 2019
item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: The polar vortex is paralyzing the Midwest. At least eight people have died in the extreme cold. Facebook and Google are in hot water for paying users to download apps that monitor their phone usage. And the U.S. and China enter their final day in high-stakes trade talks.
item.content:encoded: The polar vortex is paralyzing the Midwest. At least eight people have died in the extreme cold. Facebook and Google are in hot water for paying users to download apps that monitor their phone usage. And the U.S. and China enter their final day in high-stakes trade talks.

item.title: Wednesday, January 30th, 2019
item.description: A crucial round of trade talks with China kicks off. And lawmakers meet to negotiate border security — and avoid another shutdown. The power struggle in Venezuela intensifies and could turn violent.
item.copyright: Copyright 2015-2018 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.itunes:author: NPR
item.itunes:summary: A crucial round of trade talks with China kicks off. And lawmakers meet to negotiate border security — and avoid another shutdown. The power struggle in Venezuela intensifies and could turn violent.
item.content:encoded: A crucial round of trade talks with China kicks off. And lawmakers meet to negotiate border security — and avoid another shutdown. The power struggle in Venezuela intensifies and could turn violent.
